data.title: Wealthy Americans now hesitant to invest in France
data.meta_description: Some feel that French institutions are not working hard enough on issues of diversity and cultural education.
data.text:
Saturday, September 17, is the big day: After years of delay and setbacks, the Bibliothèque Nationale de France (BNF, France's national library) will finally reopen its Richelieu site, its splendid historic birthplace in the 2nd arrondissement of Paris.

Among the many guests, there will of course be representatives from the French government, which has paid the bulk of the €260-million price tag. But don't be surprised to hear some English: Seven American patrons have donated €2.6 million to this gigantic restoration. In particular, Mark Pigott, the discreet boss of truck manufacturer Paccar and a regular sponsor of the BNF, signed a check for €1.2 million.

This is not the end of the love affair between the French institution and America, where the ultra-rich have the habit – and duty – of giving back to the community in exchange for tax deductions. The Mellon Foundation has contributed no less than €1 million to the BNF's 2016 campaign to save the endangered heritage of libraries in the Middle East. The Getty Foundation is funding a two-year post for a young curator to study the collection of drawings from the Fontainebleau School, the French reinterpretation of Italian mannerism.

"The United States is one of the few countries where we don't have to explain who we are or what we do," said Kara Lennon-Casanova, the BNF's patronage officer. In this nation of self-made men, libraries, which are among the few places that can be accessed for free, actually play a part in social mobility.

Supporting the arts

At the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris, American benefactors also make a difference. They are responsible for 70% of donations over €1 million. Stephen Schwarzman, the founder of Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, contributed no less than €2.5 million to the renovation of the fashion galleries. The dashing billionaire Marina Kellen French contributed €1 million to the restoration of the 6,000 drawings and numerous dresses by Elsa Schiaparelli held in the collections of the Paris museum.

But American generosity rarely reaches such levels. Its contribution represents barely 3.17% of the overall patronage at the Château de Versailles. At the Musée d'Orsay, the American Friends raise around €600,000 a year, a drop in the ocean in a global budget of €60 million. "But it provides an opportunity that allows us to launch projects," said Guillaume Roux, the museum's director of patronage.

Younger generations, who do not share their elders' fantasy of France as a land of luxury and refinement, are looking more toward Asia, Latin America and Africa.
